item.title: Pope Francis, in Ecuador, Has First Chance to Shape Trip’s Message
item.description: The pope was scheduled on Monday to fly to Guayaquil, where he was to visit a sanctuary, offer an outdoor Mass and have lunch with an old friend.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY and WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Pope Francis, in Ecuador, Has First Chance to Shape Trip’s Message
item.description: The pope was scheduled on Monday to fly to Guayaquil, where he was to visit a sanctuary, offer an outdoor Mass and have lunch with an old friend.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY and WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Pope Francis on his way to celebrate an open Mass in Guayaquil, Ecuador, on Monday, as he began his visit to his home continent.

item.title: Yanis Varoufakis Resigns as Finance Minister as Greece Mulls Next Steps on Debt
item.description: While the resignation may help Athens in talks with creditors, eurozone leaders sent conflicting signals about their support.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: Yanis Varoufakis, the Greek finance minister, surrounded by journalists in Athens on Monday, shortly after he announced his resignation.

item.title: Awaiting Iran Deal, Nuclear Sleuths Gather Sophisticated Tools
item.description: Laser sensors, smart cameras and encrypted networks are at the ready to monitor a program that has been a challenge for older technologies.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD
item.media:description: Metallic seals like this one have long been used to prevent unauthorized access to nuclear equipment. New electronic and fiber-optic seals beam back confirmation that they remain intact.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. & A.: Xie Shi on the Brotherhood of Skateboarding in China’s Far West
item.description: The photographer and skateboarder based in Nanjing says that the skateboarding scene in Xinjiang is both ethnically diverse and more harmonious than the mainstream of society.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: Skateboarding in the Pamir Mountains in the Xinjiang region of China.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How to Undo the Damage in Greece
item.description: A former Greek finance minister argues that the next few days are crucial. Lenders must compromise and Tsipras must stop gambling with the livelihood of future generations.
item.dc:creator: GIKAS HARDOUVELIS

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Soften the Greek Deal
item.description: Give Tsipras what he wants and see how long he lasts. It's the only way to stop this government using a German scapegoat to hide its incompetence.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: News Analysis: With Greek ‘No’ Vote, Tsipras Wins a Victory That Could Carry a Steep Price
item.description: The Greek prime minister is likely to find it harder to strike a new financing deal quickly with European creditors.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece, second left, before a meeting with other political leaders in Athens on Monday.

item.title: Nuclear Inspectors Await Chance to Use Modern Tools in Iran
item.description: Laser sensors, smart cameras and encrypted networks are at the ready to monitor a program that has been a challenge for older technologies.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD
item.media:description: Metallic seals like this one have long been used to prevent unauthorized access to nuclear equipment. New electronic and fiber-optic seals beam back confirmation that they remain intact.

item.title: Singapore Frees Amos Yee, 16, Blogger Who Criticized Lee Kuan Yew
item.description: The sentence of four weeks’ detention for Mr. Yee, which he had already served, allowed him to be released on Monday.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Amos Yee left a Singapore courthouse on Monday, accompanied by his parents.

item.title: Muted Dismay in Asian Markets After Greek Vote
item.description: Most Asian markets fell, but not dramatically, while in mainland China, shares spiked in response to government support before reversing course.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Pope Francis Lands in Ecuador to Begin South America Trip
item.description: Francis brings his message of a church in transformation to a heavily Catholic region, and is expected to address the themes he wrote about in his encyclical on the environment.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Followers greeted Pope Frances in Quito and thousands lined his route, throwing flower petals.

item.title: Greeks in New York Talk and Cheer, Then Debate Future After Referendum
item.description: As word spread in Astoria, a Greek enclave in Queens, New York, that their countrymen had rejected the terms of the rescue package, many people in the neighborhood cheered the vote.
item.dc:creator: ANNIE CORREAL and COLLEEN WRIGHT
item.media:credit: Robert Stolarik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Menellaos Dhimalexi, center, moved to the Greek enclave of Astoria, Queens, a few months ago to find work.

item.title: Emphatic ‘No’ Prompts Greek Pride and Revelry
item.description: Celebrating the vote to say no to more austerity measures tied to a possible new bailout, Greeks gathered in Athens’ Syntagma Square and explained their frustration.
item.dc:creator: ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anthi Panagiotidou joined a large celebration of the referendum's result in Syntagma Square on Sunday.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Dominican Republic Must Stop Expulsions of Haitians
item.description: The government has abused Haitians and their kin.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: ROXANNA ALTHOLZ and LAUREL E. FLETCHER

item.title: A Mother’s Anguished Choice to Flee Myanmar and Leave One Child Behind
item.description: Lost in the diplomatic wrangling over the fate of the Rohingya refugees are the harrowing personal consequences.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jubair, 13, was left behind when his mother and siblings fled Myanmar for Malaysia. “I didn’t know about it,” he said. “She could not find me. She could not tell me.”

item.title: India’s Leader Maps Out a More Robust Digital Future
item.description: With the country lagging behind much of the world in digital infrastructure, Prime Minister Narendra Modi is pushing for greater Internet connectivity and services as well as electronics manufacturing.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India said that he wanted to substantially cut his country’s imports of electronics by 2020.

item.title: Memo From Vietnam: War Veterans Lead the Way in Reconciling Former Enemies
item.description: A visit by the leader of Vietnam’s Communist Party is seen in Vietnam and in the United States as a significant statement on the establishment of diplomatic relations.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Christian Berg for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Clark, a retired Marine, at the Fourth of July barbecue in Da Nang said Vietnamese people "really like Americans."

item.title: Russian Supply Ship Is Launched to International Space Station
item.description: A booster rocket successfully launched an unmanned cargo ship to the station, whose crew is anxiously awaiting it after the failures of two previous supply missions.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Egypt Warns Journalists Over Coverage of Militant Attacks
item.description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, facing criticism of his counterinsurgency strategy, compared reporting to a “fourth generation of warfare, and even fifth.”
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM
